TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention to one of South Australia's tourism attractions that may fall victim to this government's inability to accept responsibility for the consequences of its grandiose promises. The Australian Railway Historical Society of South Australia, better known as Steamranger, runs steam hauled locomotive tourist trains between Adelaide and the coastal town of Victor Harbour. Each year approximately 23,000 passengers travel on the three restored steam engines, making a significant contribution to the region's tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: In dishing out infrastructure projects in the 1992 One Nation statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) decided to create a standard gauge national rail highway from Brisbane to Perth via Melbourne and Adelaide. When the Adelaide-Melbourne rail line is converted to standard gauge early next year, the Steamranger will be unable to run its broad gauge trains from its Dry Creek depot to Mount Barker, from where it goes on to Goolwa and Victor Harbour. Steamranger has to relocate its depot to Mount Barker to keep operating, and the $2.1 million price tag to do so is proving to be quite an obstacle.

After pouring millions of dollars into the railway line through the now scrapped Commonwealth employment program and various grants, it would seem natural that the federal government would be eager to assist, if only to protect its investment. But, no, the federal Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has bluntly told the state Minister for Transport, Diana Laidlaw, that the government will not fund such a relocation. The state government is of the view that it is not fair and reasonable for the state to pay for Steamranger's move to Mount Barker, a view consistently held by the previous Labor government. In other words, the contribution this railway makes to the state's tourism industry—the work of hundreds of volunteers and the millions already spent in developing this attraction—is now threatened by the uncompromising stand taken by the federal government.

The state government will compromise. It is prepared to make a funding contribution, conditional on Steamranger reducing relocation costs from $2.1 million to $1.126 million and the federal government making a matching contribution. In announcing this assistance, Ms Laidlaw lamented the unfortunate omission by former Premier Bannon and his cabinet colleagues at the time to consider Steamranger's fate when agreeing to the terms of the One Nation funding in 1992. Regrettably, time is now critical in securing funding so that planning can start. I ask why the minister is prepared to offer his Maritime Union mates a $20 million-plus PAYE pay-off to restore harmony rather than genuine reform measures to the international shipping industry yet cannot find any money for Steamranger. It also seems unfair that, although the federal government has helped Steamranger before, it now will not.

In September 1989 Steamranger's Southern Encounter train service was forced to close when a 32-kilometre section of the track was ruled unsafe. But Steamranger survived. The then federal transport minister announced that Australian National would provide assistance to the value of $100,000 to help restore the track. The then state government committed a one-off grant of $275,000, while Steamranger contributed $225,000 in stocks and funds and raised another $190,000 to complete the restoration.

In announcing the grant, the then state tourism minister pointed out that the federal and state governments had contributed grants worth almost $2 million, including the $750,000 to restore the Strathalbyn to Victor Harbour line. But the federal government is now prepared to throw it all away. Understandably, my state colleague Diana Laidlaw has denounced this lack of vision. She wrote to the transport minister:

SPEECH.PARA: I am aghast and disappointed with the narrow perspective which you have taken on this matter . . . Your decision is reprehensible. It means that the future of this popular, successful tourism venture is in the balance. The potential loss of Steamranger's services is a high price to pay for the standardisation project.

One must examine the responsibilities that the federal government carries. It must not forget the ramifications on the little people as it enthuses about the big picture. It should not bow to the forces of those unions while ignoring smaller lobby groups like Steamranger, which does not have the clout needed to force results. I join the call of the South Australian transport minister and urge the federal minister to reconsider his non-compromising refusal to support the funding to relocate Steamranger to Mount Barker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record some reference to the death last week of the great philosopher Sir Karl Popper. There are particular reasons for doing that. Popper made very great contributions to world philosophy, most of them in Great Britain but also some significantly in New Zealand. He was brought up and educated in Austria. After Hitler came to power, he went, as a refugee, to New Zealand. In New Zealand he worked at the Canterbury University College at Christchurch. He was the chairman of a very influential committee which was trying to provide placement in New Zealand for refugees from Hitler's Europe. The secretary of the committee was Sir Otto Frankel, a very great plant geneticist, who is still alive and resides here in Canberra. He is 93 years of age, and he was skiing until last year. Together, Popper and Otto Frankel made a very formidable combination.

PARA.TAB: In 1945, Popper applied for the chair of philosophy at Sydney University. The appointment committee recommended his appointment, but it was then overturned by the members of the university's Senate. Despite all the experience of World War II, despite the fact that it might have been a time for us to say, `We have to be open-minded and open up our society to fresh ideas, fresh challenges,' they said, `No, we want somebody who simply represents the conventional wisdom.' They were not prepared to take on Karl Popper.

Karl then went to Britain, where, in rather an unlikely environment, he spent the next 25 years as the professor of philosophy at the London School of Economics. He made it a very great centre of philosophy. What was particularly important was his impact in thinking about science and about scientific probabilities. I had the great benefit of personal contact with him; I had the opportunity to meet him in Kenley, just outside of London, in July 1988. I knew, and I was very flattered, that he had written a detailed critique of my book Sleepers, Wake!. I spent a very important day talking to this grand old man of philosophy.

At the time, Popper's rejection by Sydney University was extremely controversial. There is no doubt that he would have made a very great impact there. The wonderful thing about Popper was not just his contribution to the philosophy of science, in which he worked for some years with another great Australian, Sir John Eccles, a Nobel prize winner—

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to uni with his son.

—I note the remark of the honourable member for Parkes. Popper was a very powerful defender of freedom. He wrote, in a sense, the definitive philosophical rejection of the doctrines of communism and of the doctrines of Nazism. His published work there is of extraordinary importance.

PARA.TAB: One of the things he also fought against was provincialism—the domination of the locality, the view that says, `There is only one way to do things, and that is the way we do them around here.' Popper was a great advocate of a fresh approach to things, but he believed you had to challenge them. One of his main arguments was that the confirmation of a theory can never be more than provisional, while its refutation will always be final. He argued that ethical standards are autonomous—that is, they are not derived from facts—hence individuals have the right to criticise authorities and institutions. He argued that progress is made possible not by a utopian approach but by readiness to make the best of existing material resources. He also argued that the proponents of an idea must be able to propose methods for testing falsifiability, leading to confirmation or refutation of the hypothesis. That is very important—perhaps some of our political parties might take it on board as well.

One of the reasons he was very critical of Marx, Freud and of some of the religious positions taken was that nobody ever said, `This is my hypothesis but, if you want to test it, this is the way you test it. This will prove whether I'm right or wrong.' They were never prepared to stand that test. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 September, along with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), I inspected the Alcoa plant at Point Henry in Geelong. That plant has three aluminium potlines and was constructed in the 1960s. As all members of the House would be aware, the honourable member for Bennelong has been instrumental in bringing about a change to the industrial relations attitude in Australia with an enterprise focus. At this plant, the change of attitude was very evident.

PARA.TAB: International competition focused the minds of the unions, the employees and the management on the fact that there had to be a change of attitude in the way they operated. The Geelong plant is one of the older plants of the Alcoa group in the world. The price of aluminium has tended to fluctuate from being fairly good to fairly bad over the past 10 years.

In 1989 it was clear that, whilst prices were fairly good, changes were needed. The management then started having discussions with its employees to bring about the necessary changes. It was indicated to the staff that the work force would be reduced from 1,000 to 600 but that there would be no sackings. The work force took this as a fair assessment and felt that it would not be let down on the undertaking that the work force would be reduced through natural attrition only.

I pay tribute to the union leadership of Mr Ted Hardcastle, who was the senior union delegate for the new Federation of Industrial, Manufacturing and Engineering Employees. He was able to persuade his union members that changes were needed, that it was in their own best interests that the plant changed—that the employees and the unions had to change their attitude—because he understood that if there was no change by the end of the next four or five years there might not be any jobs at all at Alcoa. There were seven unions in the plant at that time and he persuaded them that it was in their own interests that there be only two unions. In the end the two unions were the FIMEE and the ETU—the Electrical Trades Union.

I also place on the record the contribution of managing director, Les Davey, who was the driving force in bringing about the new culture, in conjunction with Ted Hardcastle. Les Davey introduced changes to the structure of the company, the strategy, the shared values of management and the work force, the systems, the style of operation, the skills and of course the people involved. As I mentioned before, a trust developed between the Alcoa management and the employees of that plant. This was the framework of change.

The number of unions was reduced, as I mentioned, and this reduced the number of demarcation disputes, which had been endemic in that plant and in other plants in the Geelong region. They annualised the salaries so there was no longer overtime. The arrangement of annualised salaries without overtime encouraged family life; the employees could enjoy a normal 40-hour week and enjoy their family arrangements. There was a teams approach on the plant floor, which I will refer to.

In terms of the unions, the decisions were made at the workplace, and it is clear that at that plant there was no interference from senior union figures from Sydney or Melbourne. Any possible disputes were solved at the plant level and never got to union discussions. Things like sick leave, holiday pay and family leave were decided by the teams at the workplace. Having annualised salaries meant that the job had to be done on time. There was no incentive to have more overtime, and there was a dramatic change in attitude in terms of quality and results.

The teams approach meant there were eight to 12 persons in each team and there was real discussion at the plant level. The quality of the work, the cost of the work and the cooperative approach meant that all personnel in the plant had an objective to make the Alcoa plant more profitable and world competitive. The supervisors were gone, the bosses were gone, and the teams did the job.

A team member we met said, `When I come to work at 8 o'clock in the morning I am in control of my destiny for the day because I can make real decisions that ensure I do a good day's work. This is worth while.' That was his attitude. It was obvious to the honourable member for Bennelong and myself that all people at the plant were enjoying their work. I compliment the management of Alcoa on an outstanding achievement. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I know you would be disappointed if I did not mention Jeffrey Kennett, so I will do so. However, I have come in here to speak about The Things That Matter. Before doing so, I invite the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) to contact my electorate office so he can obtain a copy of The Things That Matter document. I make this offer because one of his constituents commented in the Age last week that the honourable member for Indi was unable to provide a copy of the document when requested to do so.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. To make reflections of that sort in the House is quite unparliamentary.
—Order! There is no reflection on the member at all.
—I can well imagine that the honourable member for Indi was so ashamed and embarrassed about this document he preferred not to be involved in its distribution.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a further point of order. The member for Indi is overseas at the moment and is having reflections cast upon his character and his work as a member. That is, I submit, unparliamentary.
—Order! I suggest you are being a little bit sensitive. I have already ruled on that. There is no point of order.

—However, the more likely explanation is the Liberal Party, with its typical inefficiency, had not made the document available to its own parliamentary members. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), who is now being called `The Thing That Chatters' all over Melbourne, has put his name, literally, to a document that has absolutely no substance to it. It is because the document is so totally bereft of substance that I wonder whether the current Leader of the Opposition actually read the document at all. If he had read The Things That Matter, he would have seen, as most people have, that it contains no detail of substance. The current Leader of the Opposition has openly admitted that in the past he has signed correspondence without actually bothering to read it. Honourable members will recall that the Leader of the Opposition admitted signing a letter of support for citizen initiated referenda without reading it.

PARA.TAB: Like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), I did not have to spend too much time reading The Things That Matter. Because the Prime Minister reported that he finished reading The Things That Matter in a few minutes with his sushi, and that he read it like a Mills and Boon book, I decided to set aside only a few minutes at that time of the week when I sit down to relax and unwind. Therefore, I waited a few days after I obtained a copy and read it during the commercials of Burke's Backyard. This show, I might say, has a bit of a right wing element about it.

Three things struck me about this document. If it were not for the fact that I was reading it while watching Burke's Backyard on the TV, I could have sworn I was listening to Pig Iron Bob back in 1944—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have not checked the standing orders but I remember that another place has a standing order that states that members are expected to make speeches, not read them.
—Order! There is no point of order. That is in another place.

—He created his very own personal political power base. The power base was called the Liberal Party. Back in 1944 Menzies said, `A new movement must come into existence unhandicapped by vested political or personal interests of any kind'—except for Menzies' own interests. The first thing that struck me was that in 1994, some 50 years on, the only thing the current Leader of the Opposition could come up with was that we need a government which works for all Australians, not just some special interest groups. After 50 years the Liberals cannot think of an original word to say.

PARA.TAB: The second thing to strike me was the intention to create a department of the family with a minister who would be a cabinet minister. There are only so many ministers available. If a new ministry is created, which ministry will be abolished? Which one will it be? There is no doubt in my mind that the Leader of the Opposition intends to abolish the ministry of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. In The Things That Matter, reference was made to the government's so-called centralised bureaucratic approach to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I refer to the policy position of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, an organisation of which the current Leader of the Opposition was previously the director. This organisation, as set out in the publication Mandate to govern, advocates the abolition of the department of Aboriginal affairs.

The third thing that struck me about The Things That Matter was that it contains a subliminal support for citizen initiated referenda. It advocates the transfer of greater responsibility to local communities, allowing innovation at the local level and making government accountable as directly as practicable to the communities it serves. I conclude by making an appeal to the Liberal Party powerbrokers sitting in their leather armchairs in the Melbourne Club: this time, choose someone who at least reads what they sign. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the House some of the merits of, and the need for, a fodder subsidy scheme. I do this in light of the comments that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other government members have made this afternoon and on previous days.

PARA.TAB: My office has had many calls from constituents who have been badly affected by the present drought, which is raging in my electorate. The price of ASW wheat, which is used for feeding sheep, is $202 a tonne. That is very expensive indeed. On top of that cost are freight costs incurred in getting wheat to the property, and fuel and labour costs incurred in getting it out to the stock. Some growers are very frustrated. For example, around the Parkes area the typical call I am getting is from people who say, `I delivered the wheat to the silo at the end of last year for about half the price that I have to buy it back for now. That wheat has not moved out of the silo. I can still see the silo from my kitchen window. Why can't I buy it at a lower price? Why can't the government give me some assistance in that regard?'

An elderly couple from Coolabah, which is a very small town halfway between Nyngan and Bourke in my electorate, rang me and gave me all their details relating to this issue and said that I could use them publicly as an example. They are a 65-year-old couple who would normally be looking at winding down and retiring at this stage of life. But they have to put off their only farm assistant. They have 30,000 acres and run 8,000 sheep on their property. They are feeding out 10 tonnes of wheat a week to keep 6,000 of their sheep alive. The other 2,000 are wethers, and the couple are letting them take their chances. That couple are outlaying well in excess of $2,000 a week just to keep the sheep alive in the hope that they will make it through to January when they will be sheared.

The couple have to haul that wheat from the silos at Narromine, which is a 500 kilometre round trip. It is costing them $20 a tonne just for the freight. The state government returns half of that—$10 a tonne—to them. They have joined 4,000 ewes this year and they reckon that they will be lucky to get 200 lambs at marking time. They have put in 900 acres of oats, which did not even come up through the ground. They have prepared the land for another 1,500 acres of wheat. Fortunately they did not plant it, so they did not have the extra expense.

Many of their neighbours cannot afford this outlay every week, and their sheep are starting to die. If this drought goes on for much longer, the cacophony of voices calling for some type of assistance to be able to have the wherewithal to purchase fodder of one sort or another to keep stock alive will become much greater than it has been to date.

The alternative which the government is putting—it keeps quoting the NFF's position on this—is to do nothing. I ask the government, the NFF and the other farm bodies—the few farm bodies that have opposed this—what they are going to be advocating in a month from now, in six weeks from now or, heaven forbid, in six months from now if it has not rained by then. It is already very difficult to find hay in this country, though some should start to come through from the end of next month when, in irrigated areas, hopefully the first cuts of lucerne will be made.

Another area of great concern, which I have raised in question time twice this week, is interest rates. The example I raised in question time was that of an average couple paying about $50,000 from the recent three-quarters of one per cent rise, most of which seems to have flowed through. The proposed one per cent rise that is highly likely to come through before Christmas will add $6,000 to $8,000 to the interest bills of those people. The interest rate rises alone will more than wipe out the present drought package which has been offered—as welcome as that is.

I would like to see the government consider doing other things. There are people out there who cannot even make an untimed telephone call to their local neighbour. They are on the pastoral rate and they get charged 25c, or whatever it is, every 4 1/2 minutes. Women who would like to ring up their neighbour and have a chat for half an hour just to regain their sanity are very conscious of this charge and are reluctant to make such calls. If the government could see fit to make moves in this direction, it would be very welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of honourable members the achievements of students of the Kingscliff High School in my electorate of Richmond. Kingscliff High was recently announced the winner of the 1994 national Enviroquest, a competition run in August by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. Not only was Kingscliff High the winner, but it filled the first three places in the competition from some 40 high schools across New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The Enviroquest ran over two weeks. It focused on two unique regions of Australia—the Murray-Darling and the Great Barrier Reef. High schools across the country participated through the Key Link electronic mail network, with teams presented with an environmental problem relating to each of the regions. As they were given more clues, they had to work out what the problem was and offer ways to overcome it. Points were awarded for speed of response as well as for the quality of responses.

As the winner, Kingscliff High was given the opportunity to present to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) an environmentally based submission. On Tuesday I had the pleasure of presenting the minister with that submission. It focused on the creation of a classroom powered by alternative energy.

The proposal—I have a copy of the submission here—involves powering a classroom through alternative energy, in this case solar power. The classroom would be powered by three solar panels which would feed into a battery bank inside the classroom. The students have calculated that three solar panels would be sufficient. A large display meter would be put into place so that the students would be able to monitor the amount of power being generated and that which was consumed. They would also be able to calculate the costs of the power they were generating and consuming. This is a practical way of teaching the importance of energy consumption and the need to develop alternative energy supplies.

The Enviroquest is the most recent in a string of environmental successes for Kingscliff High since the school's Enviro Club was established some six years ago. The club has developed a good relationship with me and the former minister for the environment, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), who also met with the club during a trip it made to Canberra last year.

The club was formed by teacher Peter Langley, who has been the driving force behind the club and has been responsible for the projects undertaken by the club. The club has taken out awards such as the New South Wales Landcare Award, the ABC National Earthworm Award, the Victorian Banksia Award and the Landcare video awards. The school is also a four-time winner of the Griffith University High School Environment Award. It is not the awards that are important, it is the dedication and commitment of the students to making a positive contribution towards their local environment.

The students are currently ridding lantana from some nine hectares of littoral rainforest behind the school and are developing an outdoor classroom. That will be used by the schools from around the district for educational purposes. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) recently visited the school and spoke in glowing terms of its achievements and what it was aiming to achieve.

I had the pleasure of meeting four members of the Enviro Club who presented me with their submission last Friday week. I was impressed with their enthusiasm for what they were doing and for their awareness of the local environment. The four students that I met with—Mitchell Bryant, Misty King, Andrew Drury and Nathan Wright—were very enthusiastic about the project and also about why they picked an energy efficient classroom. One other student, Lara Maciuk, played a major role in preparing the submission but was attending the Youth Earth Symposium on the Gold Coast and was not able to be present when the submission was presented to me. The preamble to the submission states:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for the opportunity to submit this proposal to your department. We feel quite honoured. We had a great deal of fun competing in the Enviroquest competition and with most of us having lived all of our lives on the coast, we were able to gain a great deal of understanding about the problems that face our fellow Australians over the Great Dividing Range. That underlines the commitment of the students to the environment and how they wish to participate in decision making at this level.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I thank you and the House for paying attention and for giving me the opportunity to pay tribute to Kingscliff High School for its outstanding work on its local environment.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge the government's consideration in allowing me to continue with my remarks in the debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and cognate bills. I was at the stage of talking about drought proofing of properties. Bearing in mind that this is a most dreadful drought that we are having in Australia currently, I think that for the future the government will certainly need to look at drought proofing measures and taxation benefits that may be applicable to the farming community to enable it to take a lot of the preventative measures that are required to ensure that a property remains viable during what we are seeing as an extreme drought throughout Australia. Instances of these measures are on-farm water storage, on-farm grain storage and land improvements to overcome any degradation of the land that might occur as a result of the drought.

PARA.TAB: I know that the landcare program has been especially effective in my electorate, areas of which have been amongst the leaders in landcare measures. They certainly have put those programs to very effective use. The government will need to look at putting in place funding arrangements and taxation benefits that will in fact drought proof a lot of properties throughout Australia. In approaching this matter of drought relief in a bipartisan manner, there is a need for permanent provisions by the government—irrespective of who happens to be in government—for drought, so that people know precisely what their benefits are and know, before they get into a situation of extreme drought, that there will be assistance, cooperation and guidelines firmly in place that can be brought into play if such a drought should occur.

I particularly recall the situation in Victoria, when we went through a disastrous drought in 1982, and the ramifications of that and of the Ash Wednesday fires. After the fires had subsided and the extent of the damage had been assessed, the Victorian state government at the time embarked on a wide ranging program of counterdisaster measures which they put in place through legislation. Those provisions have remained in place since that time. People need to know that, if they are affected by drought or by fire, there are guidelines to assist them in understanding what relief will be made available by the government. We need to ensure that there is an understanding by people in the rural community and by other people affected by natural disasters that there is something there to assist them in each particular case.

It is absolutely vital that we ensure that people in the rural community are looked after in cases of drought, because they are one of the major export earners in Australia and they produce a lot of Australia's wealth. We have a very good reputation for the cleanliness of our agricultural product, and that reputation has spread throughout the world. People acknowledge that food produced in Australia by our rural community is in fact clean: it is acceptable worldwide, and Australia has an extremely good food production reputation.

If the proper drought relief measures are not in place, we are in serious danger of losing many of our good farmers. There has been a movement away from rural pursuits in recent years where young people have chosen to leave the farm and take up other careers. The average age of people farming in Australia has increased. We are in danger of losing even more young people from the farming community as a result of the ravages of this drought, which extends throughout Queensland and New South Wales, and now southerly down into Victoria.

The fact that drought affects everyone is borne out by what happened during the 1982 drought. Drought affects the farmers who are producing the food, it affects small business around the towns which support the rural communities, and it ultimately flows on to large business throughout capital cities. That was never more evident than during the 1982 drought. I am sure that in Queensland and New South Wales people would also be feeling the impact now in the small business communities, and it would be flowing on into Sydney and Brisbane.

Farms are not producing anything. The land is ravaged by the weather and is degraded as a result, and a lot of the topsoil is lost. People are placed in a situation where they have to face up to the elements and the deterioration of their farm property. For financial or physical reasons many of them are forced to give up and leave the farm. We have lost many good farmers as a result. Just the same, in small towns the mainstays of those communities—the small businesses—are affected. They provide goods and services to the farming community and are unable to withstand the economic and social trauma that is handed down through the deterioration of the farming pursuits. People lose their economic and social viability in those towns and they leave. Then, because of the declining population, government services are withdrawn. Many small towns are shrinking as a result of the impact of the drought we are going through now.

Those effects flow on to larger cities. Following the 1982 drought Melbourne was inundated with people who had left rural communities and had gone to Melbourne seeking employment. There is an impact on the economic activity in capital city areas because most of the manufacturers are based in the metropolitan area. Some of the large agricultural manufacturing enterprises are operating in those areas and they are seriously affected.

I want to touch on the relationship between the present drought and the difficulties that we are experiencing, and the need to put something permanently in place that will provide guidelines for the rural community in this great time of need. There are a number of parallels between our policy and the government's policy. I want to enumerate some of those. The parallels between the two policies include the provision of immediate farm family income support. This is absolutely vital. The coalition makes provision for support through a revamped farm household support scheme and the suspension of the assets test on welfare payments, the government via its new drought relief payment.

There is also improved access to Austudy for children from farm families in drought areas by exempting them from the on-farm assets test for this benefit. One thing that would exacerbate the tragedy of a drought would be if children, through economic necessity, were withdrawn from their studies. Further parallels involve greater flexibility and increased funding under the rural adjustment scheme for farmers experiencing drought in exceptional circumstances and the provision of assistance through the rural adjustment scheme for up to 12 months after the drought breaks.

This is important because the ramifications of the drought go on, even after it has rained, because of the deterioration of the land. A lot of the topsoil, a lot of trees and a lot of native grasses are lost when it does rain, particularly if there is a heavy downpour. We need to be able to rehabilitate the land and to make sure that the land becomes viable in the future.

I am certainly not condemning what the government has done. I think that it has met some of the concerns of the rural community but I am concerned that the package did nothing for small business operators in many of those drought areas because their cash flow has been absolutely decimated. We can understand that people in the farming community are going through this dreadful time when they do not have any income. There is additional pressure on small business operators who are providing them with goods and services to sustain them on the farm in the hope that the rural seasons will improve.

I would have thought that the government could have looked at providing some form of package to small business in many of those rural areas where they are servicing the farming community. Many of those small businesses will be facing a dreadful time at the moment because, whilst the income support to the families is very much welcomed, it will only be enough to sustain those families. There will not be much left after that to provide for additional services and goods from small businesses in the area and, of course, that will affect their viability. I do have some very serious concerns about the impact of the drought on small business.

A solution could have been achieved by returning severe or exceptional drought to the natural disaster relief arrangements and that would have given small business and farmers access to long-term concessional loans. I know that a loan still has to be paid back but, if it were a reasonably attractive loan on a long-term basis, interest repayments would be easier for those small businesses and it might help some of them to overcome the effects of the drought.

I am pleased to have had the opportunity to speak both before and after the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) made his announcement and I do welcome the provisions that have been made. I do not believe that drought relief should be a political issue between parties. I think that what we should be trying to do is to arrive at a bipartisan position where there are strong guidelines in place. Farmers should know what the rules of the game are if a drought descends upon them. They should know that there is provision on an ongoing basis to help them not only for the drought period but also for a period of time after the drought so that they can rehabilitate the land and get it back into full production again. I think the government should now be looking at providing long-term benefits to the farming community, particularly to farmers who want to try to drought proof their property or to make provisions for it. I know the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) would appreciate that.

Whilst Tasmania is not in the grip of this drought, there are some areas that are affected. It is probably not a drought by outback Queensland and outback New South Wales standards but certainly there has been a lower level of production for them. The member would understand that there is a need for an ongoing provision of measures for farmers, particularly in the area of drought proofing of properties. The tax benefits that might be given to farmers allow them to provide a bit of insulation against the ravages of the drought that we are currently going through. I believe the important thing is the need for long-term planning to ensure that farmers are kept on the farm. Farmers are one of the major economic stimulants to the economy and, of course, one of our greatest export earners. Their expertise should not be lost to the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). It has many parts to it and it deals with many amendments to many of the acts dealing with rural industries. I certainly support the government's amendments to the bill, which do some tidying up work. I am opposed to the opposition's amendment, which has now been made redundant by the government's announcement yesterday in relation to assisting rural Australia in dealing with the drought issues.

PARA.TAB: I basically want to support and speak about the wine industry. At the request of the wine industry, the bills allow a levy to be raised so that we can look at marketing, which includes wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program—which is so important in making sure we have integrity in all of our industries and in quality control—and how we describe Australian wine. These bills work through these issues.

There is also the research component. The Wine and Brandy Corporation has a statutory responsibility to coordinate and fund research and development undertaken on behalf of the industry. The government provides matching funds for this expenditure on a dollar for dollar basis. In other words, the government recognises that, although the industry is an expanding one and quite lucrative, there is a great deal of research and development needed to ensure the viability and continuing success of the industry.

The bill also ends the exemption that smaller winemakers, those processing less than 10 tonnes of product, had from paying a levy. As non-payers, they had no recognition in the decisions and operations of the corporation and its regulatory functions, nor were they able to seek specific assistance with research that involves the smaller wine grower. In the area where I come from in Tasmania there are small producers on small blocks. They sometimes miss out on the research opportunities from government agricultural departments and state departments. I think they also miss out on the research done in the bigger areas on how we are structuring research in the rural industries.

For a small annual fee that constitutes the minimum levy rate, smaller winemakers will have the right to represent their interests at the annual general meetings and to receive services and information from the corporation. Some of the smaller winemakers rely on larger winemakers to process grapes and to convert them into wine under instructions for a fee. The wine is then returned to the smaller winemaker to market.

Under the current legislation, the larger winemaker is seen as the producer and is liable for a levy on the wine. This cost is added to the fee charged to smaller winemakers making them pay for the levy anyway but without being able to attend, debate or vote in the industry's meetings. The act allows all winemakers to participate fully in the decision making of their industry. Many small producers will not be exporters, but the changes to the domestic market directly affect them and it is important for them to have their say.

Winemaking is becoming a very important industry in Australia. Annual production of beverage wine is about 450 million litres, from 600,000 to 700,000 tonnes of wine grapes. The gross value of production of wine grapes is approximately $300 million, and the gross value of wine sales is about $1,200 million.

Wine grapes are grown in all states of Australia, with South Australia, of course, being the main producing state. There are about 4,000 grape growers supplying about 700 wineries. This industry is a very successful value adding export industry, with exports having grown from 11 million litres—worth $21 million—in 1985-86, to 103 million litres—worth $293 million—in 1992-93, and an estimated $394 million in 1993-94.Exports now account for over a quarter of production. The industry has set a target for exports of $1 billion per annum by the year 2000—a very big ask.

Our main markets, by volume, are the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Sweden, the United States, Canada and Japan. Figures are now showing that the world wine market is saturated. In 1992, the world wine production of 29.4 billion litres exceeded consumption, which was 23 billion litres. But Australia's position in the cleaner southern hemisphere, Australia's quest for the high quality market and the fact that our wines are fruity and affordable have ensured a firm demand in the world picture. Other countries are a little nervous for their industries, as Australia's wine is beginning to be seen by connoisseurs as being in the premier league. I am sure you would agree with that, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Tasmania is benefiting from the interest of wine producers. There are 59 registered wine growers in Tasmania, and there may be a few more growing grapes as a hobby. They are spread all over the state and grow a wide variety of grapes. The Tasmanian industry is relatively young, apart from our veteran wine grower, Claud Alcorso, who started making wine as a hobby after being told that basically he could not grow grapes in Tasmania. He now has a very successful industry.

It is surprising that Tasmania was slower than other states to see the potential. I think that people did not realise that our climate is very similar to those of Rome and south-western Spain, where there is plenty of wine grown. But it may also have something to do also with the excellent Cascade and Boags beers that have been brewed for over 100 years in Tasmania. Perhaps old habits die hard in Tasmania.

However, in 1992-93 Tasmania produced 1,087 tonnes of grapes, half of which were red and half of which were white, giving Tasmania a chance for a nice range of table wines. We are certainly catching up now to some of the levels of the wines of the other states. Although we will probably never get to the same levels of production as exist in other states, because of our size, I think we can continue to produce first class wines and fit into our niche markets. I have noticed that Tasmania's wines have been seen in many mainland shows and are winning prizes across the country.

But, as in all primary industries, there are many pitfalls. Unless smaller growers have access to marketing skills and research and development expertise, competition for export markets may soon see a promising industry fail. Levies are seen as an insurance. They are the safeguard to ensure that winemaking prospers, and that Australia is competing in its own right in what has been seen in the past as a European monopoly.

The bill also deals with the Farm Household Support Act of 1992 and tidies up some matters in relation to that. The previous speaker, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), mentioned the drought issues and did touch on Tasmania. Some parts of my electorate are having a very tough time and, though conditions are not as severe as in western Queensland, where I spent some of my youth, or New South Wales, there are areas around St Marys and on the lower east coast and into the southern midlands of Tasmania which are extremely dry and where production levels are down. So any of the farmers in those areas would possibly have the opportunity of getting the benefit of some of the government's drought relief measures announced yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there drought declared areas in Tasmania?

—Yes, there are areas. The other area the previous speaker touched on which was very important was the need for a bipartisan approach to the broader picture of drought in terms of sustainability and whole farm management. I know the Farmers Federation in Tasmania is working very hard with its landcare officer to get farmers onto a whole farm management approach, and it has set some very ambitious time spans for that. The idea is to get farmers to look at their water catchment, at what coverage of trees and shrubbage exists within the farm, and to look at the farm as a whole and not one part of it at a time. We really come back to what we call sustainability, in getting agriculture to a sustainable situation. Of course, droughts and downturns in the rural area affect small towns. They have affected some of the areas in my electorate, and any assistance that we can get to some of our people will also sustain those small towns. I support the bill and the government amendments that go with it.

The proposed amendments are technical amendments to ensure that the national registration authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals, the NRA, can require a chemical company to provide certain information. The information would concern the reconsideration of chemical products registration and decisions concerning the suspension or cancellation of permits and chemical products. DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 31 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill makes a number of `technical' amendments to the Export Market Development Grants Act. Broadly, these amendments will allow better management, focus and control in relation to approved joint venture and consortium, and approved trading houses; give greater promotional focus to certain expenditure; and provide Austrade with the power to introduce and administer a system of accreditation for export grants consultants.

PARA.TAB: Included under the scheme since 1990-91, as single entity claimants, have been groupings of exporters known as approved joint venture and approved consortium. This facility allows exporters to present a group approach to markets where their aggregation of effort can demonstrate advantages over single supplier promotion. The advantage for exporters is that they remain as individuals for all other purposes under the EMDG scheme, including the ability to receive grants in their own right for their other export promotional endeavours. The facility is project based, and is at the discretion of Austrade within the confines of the act, and ministerially approved guidelines. Approved trading houses are individual entities, which, by virtue of their international network and trading expertise, are able to assist the promotion of the product of exporters who lack the funds and ability to undertake EMDG eligible promotion.

Currently Austrade has only 30 days in which to make all of the inquiries necessary to a decision whether or not to grant approved joint venture-consortium status, or approved trading house status. This period, in many instances, has proved too short to allow for consideration of all the facts. A period of 60 days should overcome this barrier to good decision making whilst, at the same time, not unduly delaying the processing of applications.

Given approved status, it is important that the entity may be monitored for adherence to the conditions of approval. The act is deficient in regard to providing Austrade with the power to reconsider approved status in the light of subsequent unsatisfactory performance, or where guidelines have been amended to reflect changed government attitude. This bill rectifies the situation.

The general limit to the number of EMD grants receivable by claimants is eight. With the focus of approval for joint venture-consortium being project specific, rather than the broad scope of activity afforded other categories of claimant, and in the light of experience, the control provided by this bill in limiting the life of approved joint venture-consortium to a three- to five-year range is seen as an important administrative control.

In lieu of non-claimable accommodation, entertainment and sustenance expenses, the scheme provides an eligible expenditure allowance of $200 per day—maximum of 21 days per overseas trip. Currently, this allowance is assessed on the basis of the prime and principal purpose of the totality of trip, rather than focusing on the actual time devoted to eligible promotional activity. This bill, on the one hand, eliminates the possibility of the scheme supporting overseas vacations and, on the other hand, does not eliminate from grants consideration those exporters who may wish to undertake limited promotional activity whilst overseas primarily for other reasons.

Finally, there are a number of consultants who provide a service to EMDG claimants with respect to the preparation and lodgment of claims. In 1992-93, over 50 per cent of claims were lodged through, or with the assistance of, consultants. As part of Austrade's enhancement of EMDG risk management, accreditation will provide a mechanism for improving the accuracy of lodged claims, thereby freeing some investigatory resources for use elsewhere within the scheme.
I commend this bill to honourable members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some fear and trepidation that I stand to make my first formal maiden speech in this extraordinary chamber, but nevertheless I will overcome this and proceed. I restate my doubts about this chamber and its modus operandi. I do not, in any way, reflect on those who are working hard to make it work. The more fundamental, threshold question is whether it should exist, and whether it should meet concurrent with the House as a whole. These are judgments to be made again, and reviewed further down the track.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the opportunity to address the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1994. Once more, there are amendments to this legislation. It is noteworthy that since 1988 there have been seven amendments to the parent act, and this is the eighth, making this probably one of the most amended pieces of legislation coming before this parliament. At an average of more than one amendment per year over the last few years, I hardly think that the government has grounds for self-congratulation, since I also note that by and large the amendments that have been introduced have been administrative, aimed at tightening up provisions that have been open to abuse. This current round of amendments is of a similar ilk.

I might add that members should not be unmindful of the fact that for each and every amending bill to go through the parliament, there is a cost tag of about $1 million—that is, by dividing the total cost of operation of the federal parliament by the pieces of legislation, amending legislation and acts of parliament that pass in the course of each 12-month period. Therefore, there is an obligation on government to be conscious of a need to approach the whole process of amending legislation on a very sensible basis, and on an efficient basis, so that it is not coming forward constantly with amendments, but so that some effort is made to group those, and to provide that the legislation in its original form is correct in the first place.

These constant reviews and changes to the scheme do not really provide a stable and secure environment for exporters. Nevertheless, we are not intending to oppose this amending legislation to this scheme, because it represents access to grants for businesses that might not otherwise qualify, and it does tighten procedures, which, by extension, may well result in savings that can be passed on to other small exporters.

It is probably no coincidence that the amendments now before us, which impact upon grants to approved trading houses and approved joint ventures, follow on the heels of the effort of the Australian National Audit Office on the export market development grants scheme—which, I might add, was a scheme found to be wanting. This raises another question: what other shortcomings in the legislation are only revealed by detailed examination.

I have said before—and I am not averse to repeating myself—it is time for this piece of legislation to be completely overhauled and for there to be a total redrafting. This should be originated, not in the rarefied environment of Austrade, but in an environment that permits the fullest and widest consultation between the interested parties, as well as with the ANAO.

I believe that it is important for this legislation to give more substantive guarantees that it is comprehensive and fulfils the needs of the export sector, while at the same time protecting the tax dollar from improper application. While I am advocating a review of legislation, I would also advocate the need for Austrade itself to be the subject of a total efficiency audit. The McKinsey report on emerging exporters, when it was brought down some time ago, was not a testament to the efficiency of Austrade. It has been 10 years since the practices of Austrade were the subject of scrutiny by the ANAO, and I fail to see why this has not been remedied.

In my view, the extent of legislative amendment does nothing to contribute to the confidence of the business community in the overall Austrade act. Indeed, the constant change that has been a feature of this piece of legislation may well contribute to greater business uncertainty.

On the issue of registration of consultants, I support the addition of provisions that will more effectively regulate the standard of consultants engaged in the preparation of EMDG claims on behalf of business. A provision such as this is long overdue. It will hopefully speed up the process of claim examination by the department and reduce delays in the delivery of grants.

I also welcome the intention of the amendment to tie grants more closely to actual promotional activity being undertaken overseas and to clarify with greater precision the conditions under which the grant will be paid. Again, I make the observation: why was this not previously addressed? I find it extraordinary that it needed an audit by the ANAO to bring about a tightening up on some of these provisions. Had it not been for the audit, I can only assume that this provision and those previously referred to relating to grants would otherwise have continued when clearly they were inappropriate. Why else would the legislation be subject to amendment?

The fact of the matter is that the government's overall approach to international trade is less than adequate. And while the export market development grants scheme probably offers some assistance to exporters, the government's longer term strategies are floundering.

The government's self-congratulation on its trade figures is a sham. We all know what the picture is: imports up, exports down. The minister is not averse to quoting figures on the success of Australia's export drive. But when we analyse the figures a very different picture emerges. The fact is that whilst the government proclaims the Asia-Pacific as Australia's most significant market, in reality our exports are losing market share. Note that I said `market share'; I did not say `volume' because one would expect the volume to be increasing, particularly as we are caught in the slipstream of growth that is taking place in the Asian region with the ASEAN economic tigers, north-east Asia and elsewhere. It is clear that our exporters are by degrees sticking in a rut and it is for government to facilitate export.

There is more to come. How can the government take any comfort from the recent report of the APEC eminent persons group? Our only claim to fame from the report is that it expresses a direction towards free trade. It is motherhood stuff, pure and simple. Of course, free trade on a sensible basis is a desirable end, but the question is how it is to be achieved. The report sheds no light on that at all, but it certainly does not close the door on some sort of discriminatory trade block. I suggest to the government that it read the small print with all of the aspects of APEC and the APEC eminent persons group report.

In the context of our trading effort, a whole lot more effort is required. I remind the chamber that, in the case of Malaysia, our trade has increased in volume—I fully acknowledge that—but it has increased in minuscule proportions to the huge growth in the Malaysian economy. As a consequence our market share of Malaysian trade has fallen by some 10 per cent. In other words, Australia is not cutting the mustard with regard to its actual trade performance in maintaining market share.

New Zealand is a case in point. New Zealand is niche market exporting to a great deal of Asia, south Asia, greater Asia and the Middle East, in a way which is taking the fight to our products more than I care to admit. New Zealand has of course done a great deal of industrial relations reform, taxation reform and waterfront reform and is extremely competitive in traditional Australian markets. I acknowledge that New Zealand has been out there securing market share, increasing market share in these dynamic economies of greater Asia and indeed right over in the Middle East.

There is always a need to be cautious when giving anecdotal evidence and comment on matters relating to trade. Nevertheless, it has to be said that it is disappointing to walk into supermarket after supermarket in the Middle East to find that it is New Zealand product which is up in lights, New Zealand dairy product which is dominating the shelves and being given the priority. You then have to search for the Australian product around the corner at the bottom of the next shelf in a way which is a matter of very real concern.

So there can be no complacency with Australia's trading effort. The coalition does not oppose the amendments before this chamber but I make the point that more work needs to be done with regard to Austrade, with regard to EMDG, and more work needs to be done to ensure that Australia maintains its market share in these growing Asian economies because we have been slipping behind in terms of market share in Indonesia, Malaysia and other Asian countries.

Let me make one final point. I recognise that the government has been attempting to bolster its trading efforts to the Asian-Pacific region of the world. I want to remind the government that that ought to be done as an effort additional to all other trading efforts, not in place of them. For example, there is eastern Europe, which I know is of interest to some members as a potential expanded trading area for Australia, southern Europe and the North American markets. We should be opening up markets in South America and the Indian rim, which itself is an area of great potential. I fully support efforts to bolster our trading performance and increase our market share into the Asian countries particularly, the ASEAN countries, north-east Asia, south Asia and India and the Middle East.

That should all be additional to our trading efforts in other regions in the world. Australia is a trading nation. By and large, it can be proud of its efforts. It can be proud of the decision taken in 1957 by John McEwen, minister for trade in the government of the day, to jump the gun and open up a trade treaty with Japan. At the time, this was done to the bitter opposition of the RSL but he showed real leadership in putting the framework approach and the facilitation that is government's role with regard to trade between Australia and Japan. This event in the 1950s underpinned huge developments such as Queensland coal, Western Australian iron ore and a raft of other activities and led to Japan being Australia's largest trading partner today.

I would add that Australia and Indonesia must not be distracted by those elements which would seek to jeopardise a normal bilateral relationship and a warm bilateral relationship between our two countries. Indonesia is our largest neighbour. It is food for thought that those elements here in Australia which pursue certain agendas—and I respect their right to demonstrate, even their right to demonstrate this day—have led to the circumstance where it is now 19 years since the president of our nearest neighbour has visited this country. That in itself has a spill-over effect on the dynamic of the bilateral relationship and the underpinning of the trading effort of private enterprise in both directions between Australia and Indonesia.

I am delighted that the Vice-President of Indonesia is visiting Australia at this time. I believe that, if the President of Indonesia finds himself able to visit Australia after this long gap, that too would be greatly appreciated. Whilst I do not approve for one moment of all that has happened in relation to East Timor over the years, I recognise the circumstances of the viewpoint of the government and the coalition with regard to East Timor overall. I say that Australia and Indonesia must have a strong bilateral relationship underpinned by a wide degree of contact, not just in the political realm—and recently senior ministers visited Canberra—not just in the business realm, with the further development of business council contact between Australia and Indonesia; but also in the cultural realm and right across the spectrum. Our two countries in this corner of the world have much to gain from a purposeful bilateral relationship underpinning expanded trading for the better standard of living of people both in Indonesia and in Australia. The coalition is not then opposed to the amending bill before the House, but I do stand by my comments of concern over the efficiency of Austrade and the need continually to amend its parent legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today to debate the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill of 1994. This bill makes a number of minor technical amendments, which I will come to later. I would first like to make some comments on the scheme itself. The Export Market Development Grants Act of 1974 contains provisions which govern the method of application and eligibility for grants, a list of claimable export oriented expenditure, and mechanisms for the review of decisions, the recovery of overpayments and the termination of grant entitlements.

PARA.TAB: The export market development grants or EMDG scheme, which is administered under that act, provides taxable cash grants of up to $250,000 per annum—$500,000 for approved trading houses—and is based primarily on expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets. Provided a person has incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in a grant year, that person will be entitled to a grant. A grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. Claimants who have received eight or more grants are not allowed to receive further grants, and claimants who have received at least two prior grants are subject to a performance test which is assessed against export earners.

Eligible expenditure includes such things as up-front marketing costs, travel expenses, special promotional literature and overseas representation. The Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, which administers the EMDG scheme, considers the main benefits of the scheme to include the points that grant funding is guaranteed by legislation, the grant is cash in hand, and the grant directly supports the majority of expenditure categories likely to be incurred by an exporter.

The EMDG scheme has been successful. It was a scheme which was first established 20 years ago by the Whitlam Labor government. The results achieved by programs such as EMDG, both in Australia and overseas, prove that governments can forge partnerships of mutual benefit with enterprises and, in doing so, can create jobs and a more positive export environment.

In 1992-93, Austrade received 2,473 EMDG claims with a value of $181 million for the 1991-92 grant year. This compared with 2,002 EMDG claims with a value of $143 million for the 1990-91 grant year. Around 96 per cent of the EMDG claims in 1991-92 were processed by Austrade before 30 June 1992. In the 1993 financial year, the EMDG scheme assisted 3,250 enterprises seeking export markets by providing about $195 million in taxable grants. These grants helped reimburse the marketing and promotional expenses of firms which are trading in some of the world's most competitive markets, in particular in Asia. The number of claimants last year was up by 31 per cent on the previous year. This indicates that more Australian companies are taking up the export challenge and looking for export opportunities to expand their businesses.

The EMDG scheme has been successful, and this was confirmed recently in an evaluation report entitled `Helping to meet the export challenge'. As the report shows, most EMDG claimants—some 70 per cent—are small to medium sized firms: those with less than $5 million in turnover a year, exports of less than $1 million, and/or fewer than 26 employees.

This is consistent with the findings of the 1993 Australian Manufacturing Council-McKinsey report into manufacturing exporters and the LEK service export study. Both studies report a trend towards smaller, innovative enterprises taking up the call to export. The number of service companies claiming EMDG is growing, and is currently at 45 per cent of all grants; with manufacturers at 37 per cent, traders 15 per cent and primary producers three per cent. However, the McKinsey report also highlighted the fact that there remains a real challenge to further increase the number of Australian manufacturers who are exporting. It is found that up to 90 per cent of Australian manufacturing companies do not export to any significant extent.

One of the more pleasing findings of the EMDG evaluation is that enterprises receiving grants have a higher commitment to exporting, in terms of employment and investment in export activities, than non-EMDG participants. On average, about half the employment of EMDG recipients is export-related.

EMDG also plays an important role in encouraging recipients to seek out new export markets. Research shows the EMDG claimants actually increase their own spending on export market promotion by more than the value of their grant. This additional spending and activity, according to the evaluation committee, results in more exports. A very important point is that the typical `mature' EMDG exporter generates additional exports of up to 15 to 25 times the value of the grant received. In other words, for every dollar that EMDG provides to mature exporters, an additional $15 to $25 is generated in export income. This is certainly good news in terms of the balance of payments and, most importantly, in terms of jobs.

Important as it is, the EMDG scheme is only one small aspect of a complex array of policies and programs in, for example, education, training and science; macro- and micro-economic management; and trade diplomacy and facilitation. The government's basic domestic trade industry strategy has been, and continues to be, to ensure that these policies work together to provide an economic environment that will enable Australian industry to be competitive and to maximise our export performance.

The government's white paper on employment and growth, Working Nation, represents the next step. It contains measures to promote research and innovation, to improve access to finance and capital, to encourage investment, to reduce the administrative burden of government regulations, to enhance labour force flexibility and to improve the skills base of the nation. Most of the measures announced in Working Nation will be of particular benefit to small and medium-sized businesses, because that is where the potential for jobs and new growth is greatest.

One particular set of issues that I want to mention briefly is aimed at strengthening the integration of trade and industry policy and program delivery. At the policy level, the Board of Industry, Trade and Investment, comprising the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), has been established to coordinate the development of strategies for trade and investment promotion, export facilitation and industry development. One of the government's primary concerns is to ensure that industry development and trade facilitation programs are delivered to industry and business effectively and seamlessly, with the maximum of impact and at the least cost to the taxpayer and the minimum of inconvenience to business.

The government also announced in Working Nation the extension of the EMDG scheme for a further five years, thereby providing assistance to, ultimately, about 5,000 exporters a year. Its expansions provide export marketing assistance to single service tourism operators and assistance for offshore marketing activities by providing low interest finance through ITES, the international trade enhancement scheme, for a further four years at $50 million a year.

Regarding the amendments themselves that are contained within this bill, the question arises of joint venture and consortia and trading houses, which are limited to a lifespan of three years unless they are renewed. Currently, once approved, a JVC or TH can exist forever, as long as it continues to meet the original eligibility criteria. The three-year lifespan introduces an automatic review every three years to ensure that the JVCs meet changing market and government requirements. Austrade is also able to respond appropriately to any new considerations that may arise. If the joint venture is continuing to meet the criteria in the guidelines, it would be expected that re-approval would be automatic.

JVCs are limited to a maximum of five grants. Currently, they are treated in the same way as independent claimants are, and may claim up to eight grants. JVCs are generally project specific, with a time duration of less than eight years. It was never intended that they be eligible for eight grants, and it is inconsistent with the nature of them, particularly as members are able to claim up to eight grants independently. The joint venture provisions give companies additional access to EMDG. Austrade would expect that, after five years, companies would have had time to develop the capacity to claim as individual claimants. They also believe that to give companies potentially 16 years in the scheme through the operation of the joint venture provisions is excessive.

There has also been an extension in the time allowed for Austrade to seek information in relation to an application for an approved JVC or TH status from 30 days to 60 days. Austrade has found that, with the rush of claims at the end of the claim year, the existing 30 days is often not enough time to analyse what information may be needed to assess an application. This extension of time will allow for better decision making. If an application is complete, Austrade will be required to give an answer within 90 days, as is currently the case.

If applications are lodged well in advance of the claim, Austrade will be able to deal with the matter more expeditiously. Austrade's experience is that neither of these assumptions can be relied on. The extension of time from 120 days—that is, the existing 30 days plus 90 days—to 150 days, being the extension of 60 plus 90, is a maximum only. It is expected that the vast majority of well prepared applications will be dealt with well within the time limits.

Austrade may also apply new ministerial guidelines to existing JVCs and THs. There is currently conflicting legal opinion about whether Austrade can apply new ministerial criteria to an approved JVC or TH and cancel them if they do not comply. This section clarifies the intention and will enable Austrade to ensure that JVCs continue to meet government objectives.

The overseas visits allowance is calculated on a daily basis under this new proposal. EMDG currently allows $200 per day as claimable expenses while on an overseas trip that is primarily for business purposes. However, Austrade is obligated to reimburse all the days of a trip where the purpose of the trip is primarily for business promotional purposes, including recreation days, and cannot reimburse business promotional days where that trip was not primarily for business. This amendment will allow Austrade to reimburse those days primarily devoted to business promotion to the exclusion of non-promotional days.

There is also a provision for the establishment of a framework for a consultant accreditation scheme. About 50 per cent of EMDG claims are prepared by consultants. Austrade is working with consultants to lift claim preparation standards but considers that a formal legislative scheme may be necessary if consultants are not responsive to cooperative efforts. This is an important part of the government's overall approach to industry policy and to trade policy as a whole. We have here a scheme which facilitates and assists small and medium-sized firms, particularly, to expand and develop export markets overseas, not only to Asia but throughout the world to a number of the locations mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party (Mr Fischer).

The scheme has to be seen as part of an overall integrated program by government to assist business. The government does not believe that we can do it all by ourselves and it would be crazy to suggest that that was the case. We have a range of businesses and industries throughout Australia which have the capacity and the potential to expand into international markets throughout the world and to develop a much better trading base for Australia. We have a responsibility, as a government, to assist that. Programs such as the export access program, and the broad changes that have come into effect out of the white paper process, will assist many firms to address these sorts of issues, in terms of their forward planning in investment and markets.

The bill helps to finetune this legislation and this scheme to make it even more effective. As I said, it is a scheme that has been expanding regularly over the last few years. It is a scheme which is held in good standing by industry, and it is a scheme which does the job of encouraging export marketing throughout Australia to all over the world. I commend the bill to the House. I note that it has support from both sides of the chamber and I wish it a speedy passage and that the changes have a speedy effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the coalition does support the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. We believe it makes a number of worthwhile changes to the current act. The purpose of the amendment is to extend the period for consideration for approved joint venture and consortium and approved trading house applications. I will not go through it all because it has pretty well all been said before, but I will pick out a few points from the Auditor-General's report. My colleague the member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), stated earlier this year that he was concerned that the export scheme was drifting and called for the government to respond promptly. This bill sets in place the mechanisms for that drifting to stop.

PARA.TAB: I come to the issue of the exporters of Australia. We all understand that the $150 million to $250 million that is involved in this scheme is but a drop in the bucket. When we think of the postwar period and the opportunities for stable trade, I suppose we must all welcome that. When we look at the opportunities in Asia, Europe, the US, South America, India, Africa, the Commonwealth of Independent States—the old Russia—and Eastern Europe, I guess it is fair to say that we have only started on this great journey of trade. It is acknowledged, overwhelmingly, that our EMDGs, as a fraction of our total exports are but a fraction of the full sum. It is more a matter of our culture. The percentage of enterprises within Australia which are currently exporting is very small. As I keep saying, we have only just started this journey.

My electorate produces something like 50 per cent of South Australia's exports, so all my life I have been aware of the world trade situation. I suppose, as a farmer, one grows up understanding what exports are all about. In terms of incentive and the overall picture for exports in Australia, I could talk all day about what we could and should do. But we are here today just to talk about the EMDGs.

I refer briefly to employment. I complimented the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) this morning when I saw him at a parliamentary committee meeting. In his book, Work for All, is a commitment that, as a country, we have forgotten how to target. Whilst the member for Fraser and I would differ on how we find jobs for all Australians, I think he and I would be totally united in that target. I can only say that every piece of energy that I can muster will go into ensuring that this country enables every Australian to have a job. Exports are critical to that and, if anyone saw the former Senator Walsh's comments last night on Lateline, he has got a few pretty good suggestions for us in that area. He suggests that we just let the mining industry get on with the job and we will do ourselves, as a country, a lot of good.
